This film came onto Netflix last Friday and I saw it is literally 75 mins so I gave it a quick watch and here is my review for it. The premise of the film sees a damaged French Soldier on the hunt after her Sister ends up in a coma.Main Character I always think it is crazy that Olga Kurylenko was a Bond Girl, it just feels like she has disappeared over the years and that is a shame, but she plays the main character here and I think she did a decent job. She gives as strong a performance as she can with the material she is given, this is a pretty damaged person and character and Olga does a good job of showing that and especially, in the first act you saw it. But there is a limit on the character for sure, she doesn't get much development and there are elements of the character that aren't ever addressed and you wonder why this is the case.Supporting Characters This film doesn't have a particularly large cats and I am going to make this section nice and quick by saying none of them are particularly great. Olga's family don't do much, the police are bland and the bad guys are clich dull characters, so this is a big weakness of the film.Story Olga's character has an interesting story about her, you can tell she isn't your average soldier and that is made clear and the film does an alright job of that and it is cool seeing her go after these bad people. But the film lacks any depth towards it, and as I said the supporting characters are generic and it just feels like someone wrote this film incredibly quickly and it holds the overall product down.Script The script is also a weak part of the film, the drama isn't there and there is literally no humour. As I said it feels like this was a script that was written really quickly and not given much thought to it and that really shows when you think about it.Style The style of the film has some decent action scenes. It is cool to see Olga going after people and it is well filmed and pretty graphic at times for sure. I also appreciated that the film doesn't overstay its welcome and drag it out for much longer then it needed. But this film has some strange pacing, there are elements of the plot that don't need to be there and it slowed the film down and feels like it was only there because this film is already short enough.Overall Overall, this is a pretty poor film. It is one that was written and made incredibly quickly and it feels rushed and despite its short run time I feel like it isn't a film that needs to be seen.

column4: Before watching Sentinelle, I knew it would be a very typical action movie about a woman seeking revenge, and had my expectations lowered. I just wanted a decent action flick to watch at night, and seeing Olga Kurylenko headline this title was another reason to go ahead with it. While I wasn't really bored since the film was economically paced (roughly 75 minutes without credits), what this film had to offer was not engaging or memorable in any way.And that is really sad since the film started out very well. First 15-20 minutes showed promise, but even the action scenes were so below par that I as an action fan was disappointed. The introduction is the only thing this film gets right; with our heroine constantly suffering from PTSD following a tragic incident, there was scope to expand on the suffering and hence make the proceedings fun, but no. Even the ending was meant to be cathartic, but it was bland, emotionless and went by without any impact.It's not completely terrible if you consider the duration and pacing; the tone is intense and hence it grabs attention from start to finish, which is what a film of this genre should do. However, what it holds our attention with isn't necessarily engaging. It quickly begins to lose the steam, many scenes feel shoddily written and it just feels disconnected as a whole. Sentinelle's got a few fight scenes, and while they're realistic, their impact worsens, especially as the film descends into a very unnecessarily twisted, boring, predictable climax that can be guessed by ANYONE.However, Olga is still pretty convincing and saves the film from a total disaster. Her performance is near-perfect, and the only reason I can say I found the film engaging. So if you are to watch this film, watch it only if you're her fan. It's a shame an action film with so much initial promise makes its action scenes feel bad and pointless, and the second half feels unintentionally funny when you realize how loosely written and connected it is. Within less than 30 minutes, I knew watching this was a huge mistake, and the rest of it just made me realize the joke's on me. I don't want to sound overtly negative, but I will be staying away from Netflix's originals for quite a time now and instead stick to watching older non-original titles just present on the site.

column3: A Beautiful and Haunting Hawaiian Film
column4: I Was a Simple Man is a beautiful, haunting, and rewarding film. I recently saw the film's premiere at Sundance (virtually) where both of the virtual screenings sold out, which is an indicator of the film's intrigue. In I Was a Simple Man, director Christopher Makoto Yogi tells the story of a dying man named Masao on the North Shore of Oahu. We realize after some interactions with family that Masao is in no way a simple man and has quite a complicated past. He is a man who fell deeply in love with his wife, but after her death decades ago he chose to have very little involvement with his children, which leaves him mostly isolated on his deathbed. I connected with this storyline deeply, particularly during this pandemic when many of us are confronting death to an extent that we never have before, and also feel incredibly isolated at the same time. Days later the film has me grappling mentally with deaths in my own family and the complex, sometimes flawed personal relationships that greatly complicate our emotions when death comes around.The story touches on a lot of interesting topics, some that might be familiar to those who have seen Yogi's previous work. The characters and script are nostalgic for an old Hawaii, one not littered with high rise hotels and apartment buildings, and one that is more green and untouched. Hawaiian nature is deeply linked to the characters and is a focal point visually, aurally, and symbolically. The complicated issue of Hawaiian statehood also creates a layered backdrop to the story that unfolds in the past.The performances by the actors and cultivated by Yogi are impressive. Constance Wu is probably the draw here, but this is not your typical Wu project. In fact, I was most appreciative of the subtle acting of relative newcomer Steve Iwamoto in the lead role, whose tanned and weathered face expressed so much. I was also impressed by Tim Chiou who played Adult Masao" during some of the most difficult times for his character.Regarding the film's style

I really enjoyed this movie. The acting was decent enough and the characters were interesting. It wasn't perfect and some scenes could've been done better, but the story is still quite moving. I had a few laughs and shed a few tears.Here's the breakdown. Cassie is always the life of the party. She goes out to a club/bar with her best friend, Lisa, one night. Cassie then decided to move the party, while an upset Lisa goes home. The next morning, Cassie is back in her apartment and wakes up with a hangover. There were many ways she could've died before this. I kept wondering when it would happen. It was very underwhelming but funny with how it went down. Watch to find out.Anyway, Cassie gets to the waiting area between Above (Heaven) and Below (hell). She meets her caseworker Angel who gives her a list of people who must be helped, in order for her to go to the Above. Cassie only has until her birthday to complete her mission. She has several rocky starts, but eventually starts finding her way. Sometimes her helpfulness is obtrusive, but everything works out in the end.I've read several other reviews and haven't seen anyone mention her outfits. When Cassie was alive, her fashion was an integral part of her identity. This didn't change just because she died. As an Angel, Cassie was able to have a different outfit each day. What I loved was that at first, her clothing is just as flashy and glamorous as when she was alive. But each day, her outfits became more plain and muted. Like she became part of the background at the end, instead of trying to stand out. I think this is because at first, Cassie's main goal was to get into the Above. How would helping those on her list benefit her? But as she was helping her friends and family, her priorities changed. Helping them live their lives without her became her new goal. She finally put others before herself and her outfits reflected her change of heart.

The morning after her 25th birthday extravaganza, Cassie (Victoria Justice) dies in a freak accident and ends up in The In-Between. Now she has to return to Earth to right her wrongs with important people in her life including best friend Lisa (Midori Francis). With the help of her guardian angel Val (Robyn Scott), Cassie has only days to make an impact on everyone's lives.Right off the bat, the concept will draw you in. There have been countless films that deal with the afterlife, some better than others. There are some nice setting throughout the make the viewing experience a little more enjoyable. Some well-timed jokes also help bring this film to life.The biggest drawback is the feeling of a drawn out episode of short-lived television series. The pacing was not there and it missed a lot of beats. The acting throughout was bearable, with Lisa and her love interest Max (Timothy Renouf) being the exception. They had great chemistry and the film would have benefited from making their story the focal point. With their quirky careers and awkward personalities, it could have been a hit.Life of the Afterparty has great intentions and there is for sure a massive market for it, but to the general audience, it misses the mark. Going full romantic comedy with Lisa and Max, and Cassie as the guardian angel match maker, would have been the better version.

A note about my rating system: because I rate on a highly subjective, relativistic scale, virtually any movie can achieve a 10/10 rating with me. After all, nothing prevents even the very cheapest of movies from telling a great story. A limited budget and amateur actors needn't cripple a movie in the hands of enthusiastic and devoted makers. And so on.Just as uninspired workmanship can flush a giant budget down the toilet, so can talent and enthusiasm carry the day for the poverty-stricken. You'd be surprised how your old aunt Mabel and best pal Cooter can reach for the stars on their Walmart lunch break last Tuesday. A 10/10 is within the grasp of any movie that cares enough to rise above itself and reach for it.And, sadly, it's precisely because of this truth that CLAW was so disappointing. For about 90% of the movie, CLAW was sailing along, high and proud, and was well on its way to getting at least a 9/10 and had the potential of even a top 10/10.And then CLAW literally self-destructed right at the finish line. The writer/director (mostly the same person) somehow lost control or simply went insane and CLAW transmogrified back into the moldy pumpkin from whence it came. Somehow, watching the movie, which had been doing so well, suddenly sprout warts out of nowhere was more disturbing than if it had simply been garbage all along.I can't be certain, of course, but the impression that I got was that the writer/director couldn't figure out how to end the movie. And so we got a cheesy ending feint of a dream sequence followed by an even worse dream-echo sequence where a full-grown Tyrannosaurus rex just shows up out of nowhere and peeks in through the window. Rawr.For most of the movie, CLAW had a sort of original TREMORS buddy/monster movie kind of vibe going for it. Structurally, it was almost identical to TREMORS where we have an unjustifiably-present monster effectively just thrown on stage (a premise you're just supposed to accept out of goodwill, apparently) and then the bulk of the movie is our unlikely duo attempting to come to terms and survive in a remote location, with no hope of help, while creatively fending off this monster that wants to eat them.In CLAW, the two leads did a surprisingly high quality acting job and were very engaging/believable. The simple setting, premise and chase-scene sensibilities in combination with engaging and believable leads was working an excellent chemistry, and then, without warning, the whole thing just took a turn for the stupid.What a shame.

column4: When a small group of soliders on a remote planet are attacked by a mysterious alien civilisation another team of soliders headed up by disgraced retired General James Ford must work together and bring the fight to the aliens before they destroy Earth and the various other civilisations...I'm really starting to get sick of Sky Movies and their misleading ratings for films; 4 stars out of 5 this rubbish got from them (so 8 out of 10 on the IMDB scale). After I watched the film I decided to look at its IMDB rating to see what others thought of the film and was relieved to see that I wasn't alone in thinking this was a stinker (it's current rating of 2.5 out of 10 speaks for itself).Although many other people will have doubtlessly explained the many flaws with this film I may as well throw my hat in the ring and give my two penneth...For a start, despite the film only running for around 85-90 minutes it is excruciatingly slow with a practically non-existent storyline; I mean there's no real definitive explanation for what the aliens wanted and why they were attacking these civilisations in the first place? At one point it's mentioned that the aliens don't believe that they can co-exist with other civilisations and therefore effectively rather than destroy the people within the civilisations. They embody the people and use them as hosts to continue their destruction (effectively creating an army). This is summed up in about 30 seconds of dialogue and isn't eluded to again. To say this film lacks depth would be an understatement!!!Still shallow sci-fi isn't always bad, but if you're not going to give your audience a deep and involving story then it's usually a good idea to provide a shedload of action, sharp dialogue, interesting characters and a sense of fun. OK it's asking a lot to see all 4 elements, but even 1 or 2 of these things may have made the film just about bearable, but honestly the film is so colourless and so devoid of personality that it becomes a challenge just to sit through it.The acting is pretty poor as well; Bruce Willis isn't the best actor in the world, but he has appeared in a lot of good films meaning that if he is working with the right director and screenwriter they know this and will play to his strengths. To be honest though, given how bad this film was I think Bruce knew he was starring in a turkey and simply didn't care and therefore put no effort in at all. Everyone else is no better with many of the cast reciting their dialogue in an emotionless manner as though they were reading from an autocue. Oh and by the way guys you're meant to be soldiers so something in the way of camaraderie wouldn't have gone a miss.Believe its abysmal IMDB rating and the 1 or 2 star reviews, save 90 minutes of your life and just skip this rubbish.

column3: ANOTHER CHEAP 'N' CHEESY SCI-FI B-MOVIE WITH WILLIS!!!
column4: EDWARD DRAKE who directed this very low-budget t.v series like Sci-fi Thriller also had written it & also had written the other Bruce Willis Sci-fi Cheapy ANTI-LIFE (2021) also & that explains why both films are so similar & i thought that as I watching it, i actually said to my wife that Willis must've gotten Deya Vu making this!!! I actually liked ANTI-LIFE better of the two but to be honest they do make a chilled evening of a Double Bill of Willis Sci-fi Thriller's. Now COSMIC SIN is set like it's other half of the Double bill, in the future but this time the world isn't destroyed but just very futuristic (with what the small budget could do) with flying cars/vehicles as well as normal cars too still & robots for a barman in the bars (Similar to Will Smith's i,Robot 2004) & lots of glowing Neon lights & things & for the most part it looks good!!! Yes it's very low-budget but i gotta admit i was impressed with alot of the look & technology they pulled off with cheap c.g.i & practical effects & the basic story is our planet has finally made contact with Alien creatures but they're hostile & when a team return from another planet that they've been stationed on, they come back possessed just like in it's close brother ANTI-LIFE & start killing everyone in the station base & here we get our team of soon-to-be heroes with the rugged old infamous ex-Commander Bruce Willis known as a warmonger due to his brutal past & it's just nice having the old skool Action legend here in such a low-budget production, even if he's only here for the paycheck!!! Willis plays his part like most these days with a calmness & a Coolness & a bad attitude just like he did in Anti-life & many other of his DTV films but i like him here & just by having him lifts its quality. We also get the great B-movie legend FRANK GRILLO who i have loved since THE PURGE: ANARCHY & his Cool, rugged & no-nonsense toughness is on display again in a leader role but to be honest he doesn't get to do the action i expected & wanted but again it's great to have the veteran side by side with Willis. There's a few other familiar faces but it's these two stars is why i wanted to even watch this.I will say this though that i would rather watch this flick or Anti-life over any of the ridiculously mega budget TRANSFORMERS films & more so than many of the over-blown budget trash that is put on the Cinema, Cosmic Sin is small scale but crams in a fun little Sci-fi action story with a Cool Willis leading it all even if he's not exactly giving it his all, still miles better than the usual Steven Seagal DTV flick. Small minimalist budget yes but i see alot of creativity went into creating the look & it's futuristic technology & it does look Good for it's budget!!! At times i got the feel & vibe of a POWER RANGERS episode or movie, especially when they gear up with body armour suits & when they fight the Alien beings (that seem like possessed humans as you Don't ever see their faces or what they really are) the villains come accross as the type that the Power Rangers would battle but hey it's a Low-budget slice of Sci-fi Thriller cheese so i just took it for that. Our team are power boosted through space & land on another planet that is fine for Humans & the rest of the Cheese fest plays on the forest planet with rebels (like STAR WARS) & the action is fine for a cheap flick with laser guns & possessed warriors that also reminded of John Carpenter's Ghost's of Mars just like ANTI-LIFE did too!!!! Many Sci-fi flicks enfluenced this as did ANTI-LIFE & like i said both written by Edward Drake but only this one was directed by him.Cosmic Sin just like Anti-life is a cheap, trashy & cheesy but fun B-movie that's nothing special or great but an easy watch & does make a nice Double bill with ANTI-LIFE. Entertaining & fun.

How much drama could there possibly be at a dance school? Sure, you have to practice your moves and navigate the egos of the other dancers, but how bad can it be? Well, as it turns out dance academy is fraught with about as much drama as a Saturday afternoon's worth of Come Dine with Me episodes.Kate was the best dancer at her school, back in her small hometown, no we're not talkin' body-popping or the foxtrot, we're talking ballet. Kate now finds herself far from home in Paris after earning a scholarship to a prestigious ballet academy, where she is suddenly a small fish in a very big pond. Every student there has one goal and one goal only, to be the best and win a contract with the Opera national de Paris. Kate soon strikes up a friendship with Marine, another American girl. Their relationship quickly becomes close, but can Kate really trust Marine, or is simply being manipulated so the coveted prize does not go to her?The first thing I have to say about Birds of Paradise is just what a good-looking film this is. First of all, the students are all beautiful, slim, and model-like. But beyond the actors dancing their hearts out the film itself is no slouch when it comes to aesthetics. The cinematography is as elegant and graceful as the ballet it is capturing and enhances many of the already impressive routines on display. In addition to this, the bird of paradise fable at the center of the story blends over into the real world, erupting in trippy dream-like sequences in which Kate and Marine come into their own and express themselves through dance in ways they never could. It should be stated that these are not dream sequences, but more an artistic representation of deep unspoken emotions.Birds of Paradise is about as French as a baguette wearing a beret, twiddling a wispy little mustache, and have casual liaisons behind his wife's back. That is to say, it's very French. A surprising portion of the dialogue is subtitled, with all the students, but Kate, at the academy able to speak it. Kate is a fish out of water and finds herself thrown in at the deep end. Those aquatic analogies clash a bit, but you get my point.Kate, played by Diana Silvers, has a firm moral center and strong connection with her equal morally virtuous father. Although the father in question is never seen, he has a strong presents throughout the film, thanks to the frequent phone calls he and Kate exchange.This is at least how she arrives at the school, but to earn the prize she finds herself constantly questioning her values and what she is willing to sacrifice to achieve greatness. Because of this Kate is a compelling character who is exposed to the reality of dancing at such a high level. The backstabbing, drugs, and bulimia, that run rife through the academy are illuminated to her and she is left in an almost impossible position. Dianna gives a compelling performance and her naivety upon her first arrival is believable, this makes it easy to root for the character when she goes up against the more experienced and cynical dancers.Marine is played by Kristine Froseth, who couldn't be more different from Kate. If Kate was a refreshing glass of Coke them Marine is mouth scorching shot of hot sauce. She's focused on the prize and wants to be the best no matter the cost and isn't afraid of making enemies. She's instantly unlikable, and seemingly a nasty little piece of work. However, throughout the film, her depth and true character are revealed resulting in a complex and emotionally rich character, who is compelling and easy to emphasize with. For me at least she was the star of the show, despite not being the protagonist, and her journey to find peace and equilibrium was the highlight of the film and a genuine surprise. Kristine gives an excellent emotionally rich performance that makes all these complex and difficult to execute ideas work seamlessly and effortlessly. This was my first exposure to the actress, but I look forward to seeing where she goes and what she does next.So, what's wrong with Birds of Paradise? Well, as far as I can tell not a whole lot. It's a compelling story with interesting characters and surprising character arcs. It doesn't talk down to the audience nor does it underline every point of the story. The fact is this is a story about two teenage girls competing to be the best dancer, and what they are willing to sacrifice to achieve that goal. It's not life or death and the fate of the world isn't at stake. The premise won't appeal to every demographic going and Birds of Paradise doesn't reach the highs of certain other ballet films that I won't mention here, but Birds of Paradise engaged me throughout and left me satisfied and surprised by the quality and richness of its characters.This intriguing balletic tale is worth seeking out and features excellent performances by some of the best up-and-coming young actors.

column3: Electric YA adaption of the genre
column4: Anger that's kept inside, raw emotions that pour into dance, romance, darkness, unbreakable bonds that break, enemies turned into friends turned into lovers turned into enemies and then friends again.. WOAH!I don't remember the last time I enjoyed an Indie film so much. Probably Joel Coen is right. Streaming is good as it lets such experimental films, that give birth to future starts, exist. They (Froseth and Silvers) were both phenomenal.My heart was pumping so fast during the entire movie. It was dark enough but at every minute I felt like it could turn from dark to scary to horrifying in a heartbeat. It's like waiting for a jump scare but way, way creepier. The music amplified every scene to an extreme. I didn't know what to expect at any moment. Will Marine betray Kate? Will Kate kill Marine? Will Marine commit suicide? Are they in love? Is Kate using Marine now? Would they ditch Felipe and dance as partners? Anything was possible. But more importantly.... The Story! It was magnificent. It's so rare that an arthouse/independent movie has a solid screenplay. It's about family, loss, friendship, sex, the roughness of first attraction, betrayal and redemption. You don't pay for perfection, you pay for romance.Froseth's Marine is probably one of the most emotionally mature characters I have ever seen in modern cinema. She was destined to become a prima donna and dance in Paris Opera but she chose the path that will make her - happy - rather than fulfill a destiny. I wonder how many of us would choose that. That's a phenomenal message to send to every young woman watching the film. She was insanely strong, she formed friendships, she showed vulnerability, she kept promises, she wasn't jealous. She had both genuine grace and raw boldness.Silvers's Kate is more of an i-have-got-this-one-chance-at-life character. Usually, in life as well, the one that has nothing to go back to is more prone to betrayal. The film does a great job depicting that dark turn. She forms a friendship and just when she feels a genuine connection everyone starts pointing out that her new friend just uses her, so she tries to get the upper hand. Ultimately, she chooses becoming M, rather than being with M. Kate's worries turn into paranoia as she starts to falsely believe that she (Kate) is the better one out of them but M will still get ahead with the help of family money. At that point she commits a bitter betrayal which changes the trajectory of the film. However, M's response to betrayal is smth out of this world. She doesn't get angry or vengeful. M (Marine) continues to root for Kate and just goes her separate path.Birds of Paradise is a quentessential picture about female rivalry, friendship and attraction. You can compare it with Suspiria and Black Swan. But trust me, it has a lot of its own going on to be different enough. People are speculating whether this is a tale of friendship or romance between the female leads. I would go with friendship. However, labeling relationships is wrong imho. As weird as this may sound but two females can have sex and still be friends and nothing more. Human relationships don't have to be structural and binary. We feel what we feel. Has it been a more queer version of the Black Swan, I believe it would have become more popular but this way, it's more neccessary. And it fills the right holes.The movie undoubtedly has its shortcoming. In particular, the transitions from strangers to enemies to friends is not smooth at all. It all happens to fast and takes to little. But for the 1.5h runtime, you couldn't hope for more.The movie also has the most exciting and suffocating sex scene I have seen since Eyes Wide Shut. You don't actually see any sex happening but the glances, the music, the touches - you call feel it all.

column3: A dance movie antidote to Cancel Culture
column4: I love movies, I love dance and I have an English Literature degree so I know a compelling story when I see one. The beauty is that you never Really know if M is sincere or not, until the end. You also don't know what will happen next, or why. Who is the villain and who is heroine?The backstory of M and her twin brother added a richer texture to the entire film, especially for me since I have boy/girl twins and I know the special bond twins have.We don't know if the rumor about M and her brother is true and it makes the rich girl M seem more human and relatable.I enjoy the fact that the story is not a trite or generic class struggle story, so common in dance movies (Flashdance, Dirty Dancing, Center Stage, Save the Last Dance etc).I never felt the sexuality was gratuitous or even disrespectful towards the young actresses (and I'm a modest person). It all seemed fitting and realistic as dance is an art that is sensual and can often leads to sexual activity that is more related to expression and power.What stands out most is that both leads fall and make huge mistakes but then redeem themselves and show grace to eachother.In these times of condemnation, snap judgements and canceling, this is a movie every young woman should watch.

column3: Finally, Indian Cinema has something as an answer to Hollywood Masterpiece 'In The Name Of The Father'. A foundational classic for changing Courtroom Drama Genre.
column4: Naandhi (2021) : Brief Review -Finally, Indian Cinema has something as an answer to Hollywood Masterpiece 'In The Name Of The Father'. A foundational classic for changing Courtroom Drama Genre. I am not sure whether everyone here have seen Hollywood Masterpiece 'In The Name Of The Father' which was based on a true story. An Innocent guy is framed for the crime which he did not commit and then his entire life becomes hell and empty. Years after, he gets a chance to fight and then justice is delivered. The film ends with the release of all those innocent guys. Naandhi has similar plot led by a single innocent young boy but it's very much fictional. Though, it uses corruption factor very strongly against the politicians and the law system. It does not end with his release but it takes the fight to next level as the guy files a case against the Police officer who framed him to seek judicially approved revenge. So, in short it's not just an answer to the Hollywood Masterpiece but also a great follow-up. The film will leave you in pain many times, it will make your heart cry but later it also shows the powerful fight back against the tormented injustice. It goes unnecessarily dramatic in the climax just to please mainstream cinelovers so definitely it hurts a little hence, i have deducted 1 point from the final rating. Rest, no complaints at all. Allari Naresh's performance is award worthy and Varalaxmi Sarathkumar is excellent too. Rest of the cast is immensely supportive. The film has good dialogues and some are just outstanding, there's like 5-6 powerful ones to hit you hard. A big shout out to director Vijay Kanakamedala who has delivered a powerful and socially important Classic on his debut. Overall, a MUST WATCH! column4: There's been a lot of negativity around this movie but it's honestly a joy. Using the British-honed style of faux documentary filmmaking, it follows a girl band Glass Heart as they work on their album at the famous Rockfield Studios in England. Their manager Mark (Nick Helm) is struggling to get Kelly (Shawkat), a pretentious and uppity American and the songwriter of the band, to crack on so they can get recording, the label breathing down his neck. Meanwhile, the band is flailing in all directions -- until the brilliant and flamboyant studio guitarist Pat (Gonzalez) arrives. I wonder if Americans will get this style of filmmaking, and that might be part of the problem, but if this had been a show like Fleabag instead of a movie, I think it would have won countless awards and would have made it majestically across the pond.Alia Shawkat is great at being disgusting here, and is a fantastic stick in the mud for Nick Helm, also turning in a fantastic performance. Chanel Cresswell is the balance for all, a believable ballast for the band. Of course, Eiza Gonzalez takes the movie away, and is addictive watching for the second half, every little eye movement and hair flick perfectly engineered for this character, moved only by Nick's grounded wife, a brilliant cameo by Dolly Wells.This is a great film, and much better than half the movies being touted as masterpieces this season. And it's a feminist piece, no gross sex scenes, breasts out, none of that. Just a properly made story and properly thought out acting.

column4: It's not Farhadi's best but I very much enjoyed this film! Amir Jadidi absolutely steals the show and puts in probably his greatest performance to date. Just watch how his acting from the first half of the film shifts drastically in the last hour - he shows incredible range and makes a name for himself here.In terms of the story, Farhadi once again throws you directly into the characters' lives and provides an interesting take on social media's greatest and most disturbing influences. It's not as entertaining as A Separation or The Salesman but I enjoyed A hero for what it is. It's a social discussion on the lengths one would go to keep their honour and reputation despite financial challenges.This had one of the best cinematography I've seen from all Farhadi's films, I recommend people to watch this expecting a slow and much darker story then his previous features.

When we discuss on movies by Asghar Farahdi we do expect to see some character swings in the screenplay and this is not an exceptional movie in this respect. However, we encounter with a more experienced director which has now become more skilled in using this technique as the other aspects of the characters result in making these swings more believable. This is exactly what he lacked in previous movies of himself except some parts in A Separation andA Beautiful City. This movie has it all; from romance to comedy; comedy to drama, drama to tragedy. The same with his previous movies, we see so many symbols available in the movie. The city of Pars, Shiraz may trigger the ancient Iranian culture of less lies and more love which has been surrounded by darkness of the social network and probably the current era difficulties which makes this movie a critical one while illustrating all we could have already heard in theory regarding bad impacts of social media on people lives. Farhadi is now capable of designing his path to the main message he has there in his mind. He speaks frankly with less metaphors compared to his previous movies and we do understand what his challenges are with the morality issues existing not only in Shiraz, Iran but also in the today's world. Characters in the movie are neither bad nor good; they are all humans and are free to challenge themselves with the lives' difficulties. Farhadi wants to anecdote his story in a way that let us think how our decisions and somehow acts might be praised or criticized by the society; the same with all heroes since the very beginning of this world who had enemies and friends, people with and people against themselves at the same time.I believe this has been one of the most geometrical original screenplays ever written. It would be wonderful not to see this among the final Oscars contenders; it has it all.Farhadi also has another time convinced the cinema fans that he is a director to remember. I can not avoid mentioning the performance of Amir Jadidi among the best ones in 2021. His Shirazi accent, the way he talks to us through his eyes and the way he pictures what he has thoroughly understood from his role in the movie. It would be hard to avoid Farhadi's ability in directing his play and if you add the other cast performances including the newcomer Sahar Goldoust as Farkhonde and Mohsen Tanabandeh as the debtor, we see excellent performances by the cast thank to their own capability and a good way of directing by Farhadi. All the other aspects also prove my word as we can experience the exact timing for original score to play, the exact angles for the cameras and the exact colors for the scene which makes Farhadi's performance a one to remember, a one to praise.I believe this movie is one of the best movies in the world of cinema and I recommend this to be watched by anyone who would like to learn something through joy of cinema.It is obviously Farhadi's best since A separation and is a certain contender for the Academy Awards this year.Amin Ghanbari- 30 October 2021.
